tweet: 7/ In summary, we show path-integration + simple bio constraints imply hexagonal grid cells, and develop methods to extract from network connectomes and activity maps (major measurement goals of @USBrainAlliance and #BRAINInitiative) a conceptual understanding of network function

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 6/ Moreover, our algorithm also disentangles the connectome to reveal hidden connectivity patterns that mediate path integration.  These patterns are not obvious at the level of individual neurons and synapses but instead arise as emergent properties of the entire connectome.  https://t.co/rd6ifgeUIB

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 5/ We then develop an algorithm to disentangle the connectome of the network to reveal hidden connectivity patterns that generate hexagonal grids  https://t.co/bVEOMvUks6

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 4/ This toroidal attractor manifold has no "end of the world", and so it enables the network to generalize path integration outside of the environment in which it was trained (black box below)  https://t.co/XOs21X3Vi6

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 3/ Now we have a complete connectome and brain activity map of a neural network that both path-integrates and generates hexagonal grid cells.  How does it work? Analysis reveals a toroidal attractor manifold with velocity dependent forces acting on it  https://t.co/8D7RMxmTzn

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 2/ Previous methods of training neural networks to path-integrate found either square grid cells, or highly heterogenous patterns.  We developed a mathematical theory explaining when and why square, heterogeneous, or hexagonal grid cells emerge in recurrent and feedforward nets  https://t.co/l0zX6CZxsM

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: @lishali88 @littmath Hmm..in an effort to understand your position - perhaps  an example would help me. In what sphere of human endeavor have we found any explanation they meets your standards of a satisfying explanation? In essence - I ask for an existence proof that such explanations are attainable

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: @littmath @lishali88 Interesting - if you your thread had started off saying that you have a notion of understanding is unattainable, and physics had not attained it - then I think no one would have argued. By the way - I *love* algebraic geometry. I used it a lot when I did string theory.

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: @littmath @lishali88 Could it be that you are defining "deeper truth" and "understanding" in such a way as to effectively make them unattainable with regards to our understanding of the natural world?  I still don't understand what you mean by these things.  I am interested though...

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: @littmath @lishali88 basically the field equations describing physical laws consist of all low order terms compatible with certain symmetries, and higher order terms are weak due to RG flow.  And in your thread you said forces are fictional. they are not.  they come from these equations....

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: @littmath @lishali88 Okay - I will try to understand what you mean.  What do you mean exactly by "deeper truth" and "understanding." One problem you raised in your thread was we don't understand why the laws we have are true. But we do have some understanding...

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: @littmath @lishali88 Physicists understand stuff!! there is so much intuition and conceptual understanding in physics. Feynman stated it well: You understand a theory if you can say something about the solutions to its equations w/o solving them.  we do that all the time!

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: @lishali88 @littmath accuracy and even regime of validity of effective field theories like general relativity and quantum electrodynamics.  this is so much more than curve fitting. But the most important point is we found the curves before they existed (black holes, grav waves, etc..)

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: @lishali88 @littmath Absolutely yes. It gets even better :) we have sophisticated mathematical and conceptual frameworks, like the renormalization group, to explain why physics at large length and time scales are only weakly perturbed by physics at shorter scales - thereby explaining the existence...

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: @lishali88 Thus there is no convincing way that the interaction of physics and mathematics over the past 500 years (and more!) could ever be described as "curve fitting."  Humans dreamed up the "curves" long before they could even be measured, let alone fit! @littmath

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: @lishali88 So time and again mathematics was invented and successfully used by physicists long before any related empirical phenomena was even observed to justify such use. In essence, *no empirical curve even existed* in our measurements before its shape was predicted to amazing precision

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: @lishali88 Lie groups were invented well before the particles they catalogue were observed. Noneuclidean geometry was invented long before Einstein used it to describe the curvature of space and time.  Schwarzschild wrote down a black hole geometry long before we saw any such thing...

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: Huh? The standard model of particle physics which *predicted* the existence of Higgs? The calculation of the electron dipole moment to 12 decimal places? General relativity which *predicted* black holes  and gravitational waves and is used for accurate GPS? Very Effective!

tweet: 17/ Therefore, cortical design principles appear to enhance coding accuracy by restricting around 90% of noise fluctuations to modes that do not limit signalling fidelity, whereas much weaker correlated noise modes inherently bound sensory cortical coding

tweet: 16/ This shows information saturates in the brain due to correlated noise. Moreover, the dominant noise mode is perpendicular to the signal and is an order of magnitude larger than the information limiting noise modes parallel to the signal

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 15/ Now, putting technology development and theory together, we arrive at our result: information in the brain does indeed saturate (green), but it does not saturate in trial shuffled data (orange) which destroys correlations ‚Äì there information grows with number of neurons  https://t.co/G5BvnNFrZp

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 14/ So these results bode well for us as a community: certain collective properties like dominant neural eigenmodes and information may be accessible, even if individual correlation coefficients will not!  I believe this will generalize to other low dimensional collective effects

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 13/ In future large scale recordings, with advances in microscopes but not in mice stamina, we will increasingly be in this modern experimental regime with many more neurons than trials....

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 12/ The same is true for accurately estimating  Fisher info: with *more* neurons, we need **fewer** trials. See the supplement ( https://t.co/DK8lAJ8wHi) for mathematical formulas for how many neurons and trials are needed to estimate eigenmodes and Fisher info at a given accuracy  https://t.co/LTWFzL4q2t

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 11/ If these large eigenvalues grow with the number of neurons, then a remarkable finding, based on well understood random matrix theory, is that with *more* neurons, we actually need **fewer** trials to correctly estimate the associated noise eigenvectors  https://t.co/7pFyQnsKcn

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 10/ So we cannot estimate any of the ~ 2 million elements of a 2000 by 2000 noise covariance matrix accurately!   But we can get around this. To estimate Fisher info and noise structure, we care about eigenmodes with large eigenvalues and their alignment to the signal direction.

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 9/ With say N=2000 neurons and P=600 trials, do we have any hope of estimating noise eigenstructure and Fisher information accurately?  This seems tough:  pairwise correlations coefficients are weak (around 0.05), and our error in estimating them is O(1/sqrt(P)) ~ 0.04.

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 8/ They measured multineural activity in response to two different oriented grating stimuli. Now we have an analytic problem: we can simultaneously measure thousands of neurons, but we cannot obtain as many trials because of biological limitations in recording time.

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 7/ First, my colleagues in the Schnitzer lab, lead by Oleg, built a 16 laser beam two-photon microscope that enabled recordings of more than two thousand neurons over very large fields of view covering mouse visual cortex with frame rates of 7 to 17 Hz  https://t.co/oeHqU82Poc

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 6/ This hypothesis was nicely articulated by @pouget_alex and colleagues:  https://t.co/r9Ic9IZBNx  But can we directly observe the saturation of information in the brain and how many neurons does it take to saturate?  We developed technology and theory to find this out

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 5/ A key hypothesis is that trial by trial neural fluctuations are correlated so that the noise (covariance ellipsoids below) spreads out along the signal direction (difference in mean responses) as you add more neurons, yielding Fisher information saturating with neuron number  https://t.co/qqGBdShgnY

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 4/ The reason this is a puzzle is that the animal has many more neurons that respond differentially to the two stimuli, so why can‚Äôt it average over the neurons, achieving a signal to noise ratio (SNR) or Fisher info proportional to the number of neurons?

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 3/ We address an old puzzle: namely that when an animal has to discriminate between two visual stimuli, it often can‚Äôt do much better than the performance of an ideal observer that only has access to a small number of neurons in the relevant brain region processing those stimuli

tweet: 11/ Thanks again to fun and awesome collaborators @SamOcko, @kiahhardcastle and @lisa_giocomo!

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 10/ And a special case of our theory explains how grid cells respond to altered virtual reality experiments in which landmarks and path integration disagree. If the disagreement is small (large) grid cells phase shift (remap). See our paper @NatureNeuro:  https://t.co/FrhgeBo6Wx

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 9/ Our theory makes a prediction that we could create topological defects in grid cells through specific environmental manipulations.  This suggests new experiments!  https://t.co/Nci0HWgU9k

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 8/ Our theory naturally explains why and how grid cells become deformed in irregular environments; boundaries pin the attractor bump, and so firing in the interior is influenced by the boundary pinning. The left figure is data, the right figure is simulations of our theory  https://t.co/zA844rA6Md

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 7/ First, we predict grid cell activity patterns will be sucked towards the last border the animal just came from; this turns out to be true!  They get sucked about 2cm towards the last border; note this may be a feature not a bug (biased estimators can outperform unbiased ones)  https://t.co/Pjj1EJxOc4

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 6/ Because neural learning reduces to this emergent spring mass system, exploration of a new environment will provably self-organize a consistent map of space; but this theory makes testable predictions about grid cells too, assuming borders are prominent landmarks‚Ä¶

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 5/ In fact we prove the combined neural/synaptic dynamics reduces to a spring mass system: each landmark cell‚Äôs efferent synapses reduces to a particle in physical space; pairs of particles are connected by springs w/ rest length = the physical distance separating the landmarks  https://t.co/htsW8jssjA

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 4/ We prove analytically that the combined neural dynamics and synaptic learning solves a fundamental consistency condition: if landmark A pins the attractor bump to a certain state, motion from landmark A to B moves it precisely to the state that landmark B pins the bump to  https://t.co/tpaN7LRUFz

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 3/ We show a simple attractor network with velocity inputs that move an attractor bump and landmark inputs that pin the attractor bump can do this - with Hebbian plasticity from landmark inputs to the attractor network.  https://t.co/ShthxD43qz

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 2/ We ask: how do we learn where we are?  two info sources are needed: 1) our recent history of velocity; 2) what landmarks we have encountered. How can neurons/synapses fuse these two sources to build a consistent spatial map as we explore a new place we have never seen before?

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: @tdverstynen @gershbrain Yep; being tongue in cheek. I agree one should state assumptions underlying any analysis - statistical or not. When put that way, the baroque statement "no statistical analysis is model free" becomes less mysterious (and interesting).

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: @tdverstynen @gershbrain I have a new tongue in cheek conjecture:  The "statement no statistical analysis is model-free" is true if and only if it is uninteresting :)

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: @gershbrain Yes - I suppose for suitable definitions "statistical" and "interpretation" you could prove the non-existence of model free.  For example: statistical interpretation often boils down to model selection and, tautologically, model selection cannot be model free.

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: @gershbrain Is computing the mean a model free analysis? It minimizes square distance from all data points. It also happens to be the ML estimate of a Gaussian with identity covariance; u could use that to argue computing the mean is not model free - but why be so mean to the poor mean? :)

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 8/ Thus the theory of cell-types is catching up to experiments in the retina! Would be interesting to theorize about cell type diversity in higher cortex; see our opinion piece with @kiahhardcastle and @lisa_giocomo in @NatureNeuro:  https://t.co/qchyCmOpDW

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 7/ In the works: we can account for further cell-type diversity by considering the statistics of colors in natural movies, thereby deriving the properties of the next most numerous primate retinal ganglion cell type: small bistratified cells

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 6/  We have two cell-types rather than one, with each cell-type specializing to process one of the two distinct tails of natural movie power spectra.  Optimal cell-types correspond to midget cells focusing on tail number one, and parasol cells focusing on tail number two

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 5/ Basically, the power spectrum of natural movies has two distinct tails: a first extending to high spatial / low temporal frequencies, and the second extending to high temporal / low spatial frequencies.  We prove mathematically that we obtain more efficient neural codes if‚Ä¶

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 4/ We show detailed properties of midget/parasol cells (small/large spatial receptive fields, slow/fast temporal filtering, high/low number density, low/high contrast sensitivity) all arise as a simple emergent property of encoding natural movies at high fidelity with few spikes

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 3/ Interestingly, even in primate retina where cell type diversity is best documented, we haven‚Äôt had a good theory of cell types.  We provide a first principles mathematical derivation of cell types spanning 70% of retinal ganglion cells, including ON/OFF midget/parasol cells

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 2/ Cell types are a big deal in experimental neuroscience ‚Äì see e.g. @AllenInstitute, @czbiohub, and @USBrainAlliance initiatives documenting cell type diversity; but theory has lagged behind in explaining why we have such cell type diversity; we try to fix this in the retina...

name: Surya Ganguli

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 11/ Surprising how much can be explained using the nonlinear dynamics of learning in deep linear nets; but of course much left unexplained:  context dependence, causal inference, binding; many adventures left. Thanks again to awesome collaborators Andrew Saxe and Jay McClelland!

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 10/ Representational similarity analysis (RSA):  two deep linear nets trained on the same data from diff initial weights will learn hidden reps with the same similarity structure *if and only if* learning is optimal (smallest norm weights): RSA = invariant of optimal learning!

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 9/ Changing patterns of inductive generalization over development: why children and neural networks over-generalize early in learning and then progressively restrict their patterns of generalization

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 8/ Basic level effects: explaining why neural networks may preferentially learn and name structure at a basic level of hierarchy (i.e. bird), rather than superordinate (i.e. animal) or subordinate (i.e. robin) levels

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 7/ Some categories are more ‚Äúcoherent‚Äù (i.e. set of dogs), and others are not (i.e. set of ‚Äúall things blue.‚Äù ).  We define a quantitative notion of category coherence and prove mathematically that more coherent categories are learned faster

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 6/ The notion of typical versus atypical members of a category and why neural networks can more quickly semantically process typical members (i.e. a canary is a typical bird but an ostrich is not)

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 5/ The existence of a firm belief in incorrect facts over child development which cannot be explained by classical association models since data supporting such facts are never present in the world: i.e. ‚Äúworms have bones‚Äù

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 4/ Rapid stage-like transitions in developmental learning in which children seem to learn nothing for a while and then suddenly acquire a new concept

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 3/ The hierarchical differentiation of concepts over infant semantic development: children acquire broad categorical distinctions before they acquire fine categorical distinctions

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 2/ We study how many phenomena in human semantic cognition arise in deep neural networks, and how these phenomena can be understood analytically in a simple deep linear network.  Such phenomena include‚Ä¶

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 15/ For details about these latter predictions, see our preprint "Emergent elasticity in the neural code for space," which analyzes how neural dynamics and synaptic plasticity can combine landmarks and velocity to generate consistent internal maps of space  https://t.co/85nLLepLup

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 14/  several phenomena including: (a) grid cell firing fields get sucked in slightly towards the last border the mouse came from (b) why grid cell firing fields become distorted in irregular environments (c) the possibility of topological defects in grid cells

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 13/ This model makes quantitative predictions about when grid cells will phase shift or remap in response to altered virtual reality scenarios.  We also analyze how this landmark correction model is learned through synaptic plasticity, and how it also predicts/explains...

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 12/ The synch phase corresponds to a small disagreement between velocity integration and visual landmarks and grid cells simply phase shift; the desynch phase corresponds to a large disagreement between velocity and landmarks... then grid cells break free of landmarks and remap!

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 11/ A lot is known about coupled oscillators w/ diff frequencies:  when the frequency diff is small, they synchronize at a fixed phase lag; but when the frequency diff is large, they desynchronize.  This synch/desynch phase transition can then be connected to grid cell remapping!

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 10/ matches the rate of advance of the attractor phase due to velocity integration. But if one alters the relationship between steps taken and how much the visual scene advances, then the  landmark oscillator and the velocity integration oscillator have different frequencies

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 9/ The sequence of landmark pinning phases is a second oscillator, which is coupled to the first oscillator - the velocity driven attractor phase. in a learned environment, the two oscillators have the same frequency.  This equality means the rate of advance of visual landmarks

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 8/ represents the position of an activity bump on an attractor ring. Velocity integration moves this phase around the ring yielding an abstract oscillator. But successive visual landmarks also correct the attractor phase by pinning it at different phases for different landmarks

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 7/ Lead by Sam Ocko, we developed a simple two dimensional theoretical model that explained these observations.  We modeled grid cells in 1D as an attractor based path integration network that is corrected by visual landmarks. The attractor state is described by a phase which ...

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 6/ Grid cells that compute position phase shift their firing patterns in the virtual environment when the discrepancy between self-motion and visual cues is small - but they completely remap when the discrepancy is large!

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 5/ But virtual reality alterations revealed interesting principles: Speed cells are more driven by optic flow when it is faster than expected, but are more driven by self-motion when optic flow is slower than expected.  And then the grid cells...

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 4/ How does the brain react to this virtual world?  Entorhinal border cells in the physical world behaved like visual landmark cells in the virtual world.  And speed cells and grid cells in the physical world remained speed cells and grid cells in the virtual world.

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 3/ But how do neurons in the brain perform these multimodal computations?  To figure this out @malcgcamp created virtual reality environments in which he could alter the very relationship between how many steps a mouse takes and how much it moves in the virtual visual environment

name: Surya Ganguli
tweet: 2/ Disparate signals can contribute to velocity and position computations: how fast your legs move (self-motion) + how fast the visual scene moves (optic flow) can be combined to compute velocity. And velocity integration + landmark correction can be combined to compute position
